p: Alginates are naturally occurring, indigestible polysaccharides commonly produced by and refined from various genera of brown algae (mainly Laminaria hyperborean, Macrocystis pyrifera, Ascophyllum nodosum; lesser extent Laminaria digitate, Laminaria japonica, Eclonia maxima, Lesonia negrescens, Sargassum sp.) [ 26, 27, 28, 29, 30]. Some bacteria such as Azotobacter vinelandii or mucoid strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa also synthesize alginate like polymers as exopolysaccharide (i.e., extracellular polymeric substances, EPSs) [ 29, 31]. Alginate production from Marine algae [ 32] and A. vinelandii [ 33] are explained elsewhere.
